definitions.definition: the quality of something, such as a situation or an argument, that makes it easy to understand

examples.text: a need for greater transparency in legal documents
The police reforms will ensure greater transparency and accountability.

definitions.definition: the quality of something, such as glass, that allows you to see through it
a picture printed on a piece of film, usually in a frame, that can be shown on a screen by shining light through the film

examples.text: an overhead transparency *(= used with an )*

definitions.definition: the quality in something, such as an excuse or a lie, that allows somebody to see the truth easily

examples.text: They were shocked by the transparency of his lies.

wordOrigin: late 16th cent. (as a general term denoting a transparent object): from medieval Latin transparentia, from transparent- ‘shining through’, from Latin transparere, from trans- ‘through’ + parere ‘appear’.
